page.title: 02LOCAL HISTORY 1
page.content:
To relate back to the dawn of Hope and Caergwrle's history we have to take a journey back in time to about 4000 BC when a short roundheaded tribe - the Iberians - are believed to have settled in Britain. They are thought to have been responsible for one of the area's oldest relics - the Sarn - a stone causeway built to bridge the River Alyn. {(Local history)
The area can also be attributed to being a scene of mass burials, since 4 sites in Hope could be singled out as prehistoric cemeteries. The set of 4 mounds or 'barrows' could have been 'garnished' by food vessels. One was found in 1823 in an irrigated field by workmen and is now a coveted memorial of the area's prehistory. It is known as the Caergwrle Bowl and is kept in the National Museum in Cardiff.
